sub_topic: Finding the determinant of a matrix
message_2:
To calculate the determinant of a 3x3 matrix, we can use the following formula:

det(A) = a(ei − fh) − b(di − fg) + c(dh − eg)

where the matrix A is:

\begin{bmatrix}
a & b & c\\
d & e & f\\
g & h & i
\end{bmatrix}

In this case, the matrix is:

\begin{bmatrix}
2 & 5 & -3\\
0 & -1 & 4\\
1 & 2 & 1
\end{bmatrix}

So, a = 2, b = 5, c = -3, d = 0, e = -1, f = 4, g = 1, h = 2, and i = 1.

Now, we can plug these values into the formula:

det(A) = 2((-1)(1) - (4)(2)) - 5(0 - (-3)(1)) - 3(0 - (4)(1))

det(A) = 2(-1 - 8) - 5(0 + 3) + 3(0 - 4)

det(A) = 2(-9) - 15 + 12

det(A) = -18 - 15 + 12

det(A) = -21

So, the determinant of the given 3x3 matrix is -21.
